writing_prompt: When Arthur stumbles upon the scars Merlin has been hiding, he demands answers—but the truth behind them reveals more than either of them expected, leaving their bond forever changed.
story:
Arthur's eyes narrowed as he tugged off his chainmail, the weight of the day's training settling heavily on his shoulders. He stretched his arms, feeling the pull of overworked muscles, before turning to see Merlin fumbling with his own tunic. The idiot had tripped over a loose stone earlier, and Arthur had half a mind to lecture him about paying more attention. But something stopped him. A glimpse of pale skin, marred with lines that shouldn't be there, caught his eye.

“Merlin, what are those?” Arthur's voice was sharp, a mix of curiosity and concern. He stepped closer, his eyes fixed on the crisscross of scars that decorated Merlin's back and arms. They looked old, yet the pain behind them seemed fresh.

Merlin's head snapped up, panic flashing in his eyes before he could mask it. He quickly pulled his tunic back into place, attempting to laugh it off. "Oh, these? Just clumsy accidents, you know me."

But Arthur wasn't convinced. He grabbed Merlin's wrist, gently but firmly, and turned him around to face him. "Don't lie to me, Merlin. These aren’t from tripping over your own feet. What happened?"

Merlin's eyes darted around the room, searching for an escape. But there was none. He sighed, resignation settling over him. "It's... it's a long story, Arthur. And not one I'm particularly proud of."

Arthur's grip softened, his expression shifting to one of genuine concern. "I want to know, Merlin. Please."

Merlin nodded slowly, knowing that he owed Arthur the truth. He took a deep breath, memories flooding back as he began to speak. "It started long before I came to Camelot. When I was just a boy, my magic... it wasn't something I could control. And in Ealdor, magic was feared."

Arthur's eyes widened, but he remained silent, letting Merlin continue.

"My mother did her best to protect me, but there were times when the villagers... they weren't so understanding. They saw me as a threat, a danger to their way of life. So, they took matters into their own hands." Merlin's voice wavered, and he looked away, unable to meet Arthur's gaze.

"They... they hurt you?" Arthur's voice was barely a whisper, as if he couldn't bear to hear the answer.

Merlin nodded, tears glistening in his eyes. "They thought if they punished me enough, the magic would go away. But it never did. It only made me more determined to hide it, to protect those I cared about."

Arthur's heart ached at the pain in Merlin's voice. He reached out, gently placing a hand on Merlin's shoulder. "I'm so sorry, Merlin. I had no idea."

Merlin shook his head, a bitter smile on his lips. "It's not your fault, Arthur. And it's not just the villagers. When I came to Camelot, I thought I could start fresh. But... there were other dangers. Sorcerers, creatures, even some of your father's men. They all left their marks."

Arthur's brow furrowed, anger simmering beneath the surface. "My father's men? Who?"

Merlin hesitated, then shrugged. "They were just doing their duty, enforcing the laws against magic. They didn't know I was your servant, and even if they did, it wouldn't have mattered. Magic is forbidden, and they were following orders."

Arthur's jaw clenched, a mix of anger and guilt churning within him. "I swear, Merlin, if I had known..."

Merlin placed a hand on Arthur's arm, his touch gentle. "I know, Arthur. And that's why I never told you. I didn't want to burden you with my past. You've had enough to deal with."

Arthur shook his head, his eyes filled with determination. "You're not a burden, Merlin. You're my friend. And I should have been there for you."

Merlin smiled, a genuine warmth in his eyes. "You've been there more than you know, Arthur. And despite everything, I wouldn't change a thing. Because it's brought me here, to you."

Arthur's heart swelled at the words, and he pulled Merlin into a tight embrace. "You're not alone anymore, Merlin. We'll face whatever comes together."

Merlin hugged him back, feeling a weight lift from his shoulders. For the first time in a long while, he felt truly seen, scars and all.

As they pulled apart, Arthur met Merlin's gaze, a newfound determination in his eyes. "And we'll start by making sure no one else suffers because of magic. Not in Camelot. Not anymore."

Merlin nodded, hope flickering in his chest. "Together."

With that, they stepped out of the room, side by side, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead. Their bond, now forged in the fires of truth, was stronger than ever, and neither of them would ever have to face their demons alone again.

The room seemed to hold its breath as the door closed behind them. The setting sun cast long shadows, painting the walls in hues of gold and crimson. Arthur's chambers, usually a place of strategy and rest, had become a crucible where secrets were laid bare and bonds were reforged.

As they walked through the corridors of Camelot, the weight of the revelation settled between them, yet it felt oddly light. Merlin glanced at Arthur, studying the prince's profile. There was a newfound intensity in Arthur's eyes, a determination that made Merlin's heart ache with gratitude.

"Arthur," Merlin began, his voice soft, "I never wanted you to feel responsible for my scars. They’re a part of my past, but they don't define me."

Arthur's steps faltered for a moment, and he turned to face Merlin. "But they do define part of who you are, Merlin. They show your strength, your resilience. And knowing what you've endured... it makes me respect you even more."

Merlin felt a flush of warmth at Arthur's words. He had always feared that revealing his scars would make him seem weak or pitiable. But Arthur's respect was a balm to his soul, a validation of his worth beyond his magic.

They continued walking, the night air cool against their skin. The torches lining the walls flickered, casting dancing shadows that seemed to mirror the tumult of emotions within them.

As they approached the courtyard, Arthur paused, his gaze fixed on the horizon where the first stars began to twinkle. "Merlin, I promise you this: Camelot will become a place where people like you don't have to hide. Where magic isn't feared but understood."

Merlin felt a surge of hope at Arthur's words. He knew it wouldn't be easy. Uther's hatred of magic was deeply ingrained, and the people of Camelot had been taught to fear it. But with Arthur's determination and his own willingness to fight for a better future, he believed it was possible.

"And I promise to stand by you, Arthur," Merlin said, his voice steady. "To help you build that future. No matter what it takes."

Arthur smiled, a rare, genuine smile that lit up his face. "Together, then."

They stood there for a moment, the cool breeze carrying the scent of the night's blooming flowers. It was a moment of peace, a quiet before the storm of change that they both knew was coming.

The sound of footsteps approaching broke the silence, and they turned to see Gwen hurrying towards them, her expression one of concern. "Arthur, Merlin, is everything alright?"

Arthur glanced at Merlin, a silent question in his eyes. Merlin nodded, giving him permission to share the truth.

"Gwen," Arthur began, his tone gentle yet firm, "we've discovered something important. Something that will change Camelot."

Gwen's eyes widened, and she looked between them, sensing the gravity of the situation. "What is it?"

Merlin stepped forward, taking a deep breath. "It's about magic, Gwen. And about the scars we carry, both seen and unseen."

As they began to explain, the bond between them grew stronger, fortified by the shared truth and the promise of a better future. And in that moment, they knew that whatever challenges lay ahead, they would face them together, united by their friendship and their unwavering commitment to a Camelot where all could live freely.

The following days were a whirlwind of strategy and quiet conversations, with Arthur and Merlin navigating the delicate balance of revealing the truth while maintaining the safety of the kingdom. Arthur’s chambers became a hub of whispered discussions, plans laid out on parchment, and the occasional heated argument.

"Merlin, if we go about this too quickly, we'll risk inciting panic," Arthur cautioned, his fingers tracing over a map of Camelot spread across the wooden table.

"I know, Arthur, but if we wait too long, we risk losing the momentum. People need to see that you're serious about this change," Merlin countered, his eyes flashing with determination.

Their debates were intense, but the mutual respect they had for each other’s perspectives ensured they always found common ground. Gwen and Gaius were brought into the fold, their wisdom and support proving invaluable.

Gaius, with his vast knowledge of both medicine and magic, helped them draft new laws that sought to integrate magic into society rather than ostracize it. Gwen, with her deep understanding of the people, provided insights into how best to communicate these changes without inciting fear.

One evening, as they poured over yet another draft of their proclamation, Arthur leaned back in his chair, rubbing his temples. "How did my father manage to keep this kingdom running without losing his mind?"

Merlin chuckled, the sound a welcome break from the tension. "He had you, for one. And he ruled through fear, which is easier in some ways. What we’re trying to do is much harder, but infinitely more worthwhile."

Arthur looked at Merlin, the weight of his words sinking in. "Thank you, Merlin. For everything. I couldn't do this without you."

Merlin met his gaze, his eyes softening. "And I wouldn't want to do this without you, Arthur."

The night of the proclamation arrived, and the courtyard was filled with the murmurs of the gathered crowd. The atmosphere was thick with anticipation and apprehension. Arthur stood on the steps of the castle, Merlin at his side, both of them dressed in their finest. This moment would be etched into the history of Camelot.

Arthur took a deep breath, his voice steady and clear as he began to speak. "People of Camelot, today we stand on the precipice of change. For too long, we have allowed fear and misunderstanding to dictate our actions. But no more."

He paused, letting his words sink in. The crowd was silent, their attention rapt.

"Magic is a part of our world. It is neither inherently good nor evil; it is how we choose to use it that defines its nature. From this day forth, Camelot will no longer persecute those who possess magic. Instead, we will strive to understand and integrate it into our society, for the benefit of all."

There were gasps and murmurs from the crowd, but Arthur continued, his voice unwavering. "This will not be an easy journey, and there will be challenges along the way. But I believe in the strength and resilience of Camelot. Together, we can build a kingdom where all are free to live without fear."

As Arthur finished, Merlin stepped forward, his heart pounding in his chest. "I stand before you as someone who has lived in fear of his own magic. But I also stand before you as someone who believes in this vision for Camelot. With your support, we can make this a reality."

The crowd erupted into a mix of cheers and anxious whispers. The path ahead was uncertain, but the first steps had been taken. Arthur and Merlin stood side by side, their bond stronger than ever, ready to face whatever the future held.

And as the first stars began to twinkle in the night sky, the promise of a new dawn for Camelot shone brightly in their hearts.

writing_prompt: A scruffy young raven, outcast by her kin, takes up residence in your chambers, much to the dismay of your court. But as the bird grows into a striking and mischievous companion, you realize she may be more than just a pet—she's family.
story:
Thorin Oakenshield had never been one to shy away from the unconventional. From reclaiming Erebor to forging alliances with elves and men, he had always followed his heart, no matter how unorthodox the path. So when the scruffy young raven first appeared in his chambers, pecking at the window with a tenacious determination, he felt a flicker of curiosity rather than the disdain that filled the eyes of his court.

The bird was a ragged mess, feathers askew and eyes sharp with a mix of defiance and desperation. She hopped in, uninvited but undeterred, and made herself comfortable on the arm of his chair. Thorin couldn't help but admire her audacity. She reminded him, in some small way, of himself.

The court, however, was less amused. Balin, ever the voice of reason, looked up from the scrolls he was organizing and muttered under his breath about the potential for disease. Dwalin, who valued order and discipline, eyed the bird with a mixture of suspicion and irritation. Even Bilbo, who had grown fond of many unusual creatures during his adventures, seemed taken aback by the raven’s sudden appearance.

"Thorin," Balin began, his voice laced with concern, "a bird in the chambers? Especially one in such a state... It’s hardly appropriate."

Thorin waved a hand dismissively. "She's just a bird, Balin. Perhaps she seeks refuge."

"Refuge or not," Dwalin grumbled, "she's a mess. And she'll make a mess of your chambers."

The raven, as if understanding the criticism, fluffed her feathers and let out a sharp caw that echoed through the stone walls. Thorin chuckled, a rare sound that drew surprised glances from his companions. "She stays," he declared, his tone brooking no argument.

Days turned into weeks, and the raven, whom Thorin named Gwenyth, settled into life within Erebor. Her transformation was remarkable. The once scruffy bird grew sleek and glossy, her feathers turning a deep, iridescent black that shimmered in the firelight. But it wasn't just her appearance that changed; her personality blossomed as well.

Gwenyth was a creature of mischief and intelligence. She had a penchant for stealing shiny objects—rings, coins, and even the occasional gem—hiding them in nooks and crannies only she could find. Thorin often found himself chasing after her, a bemused smile on his face as he retrieved his missing belongings.

Despite the initial dismay, the court began to warm to Gwenyth’s antics. Balin, who had always been a scholar at heart, found himself fascinated by her intelligence. He spent hours observing her, making notes on her behavior and marveling at her cleverness. Dwalin, though still gruff, would leave small morsels of food for her, grumbling about "keeping her out of trouble." And Bilbo, ever the hobbit with a soft spot for all living things, would sit by the fire, telling her stories of the Shire as she perched on his shoulder, listening intently.

One evening, as Thorin sat by the hearth, Gwenyth landed on his knee, a small, polished stone clutched in her beak. She dropped it into his hand and cawed softly, her eyes shining with what Thorin could only describe as affection. He stroked her feathers, feeling the warmth of her small body through his calloused fingers.

"You've made quite the impression, haven't you?" he murmured. Gwenyth tilted her head, as if considering his words, before hopping up to his shoulder. She nuzzled against his cheek, a gesture so tender that Thorin felt a lump rise in his throat.

The days grew shorter, and the air colder, as winter settled over Erebor. The grand halls, once filled with the clamor of rebuilding, now echoed with the sounds of celebration and camaraderie. Thorin found solace in these moments, surrounded by his friends and kin, but it was the presence of Gwenyth that brought a unique comfort to his heart.

One particularly cold night, as a blizzard howled outside, Thorin sat in his chambers, the fire casting a warm glow across the room. Gwenyth was perched on the back of his chair, her feathers fluffed up against the chill. Thorin reached up to stroke her, and she leaned into his touch, her eyes half-closed in contentment.

It was in these quiet moments that Thorin reflected on the unexpected bond they had formed. Gwenyth had become more than just a companion; she was a reminder of resilience and acceptance. She had faced rejection and hardship, much like himself, and yet she had found a place where she belonged.

One morning, as the first light of dawn filtered through the windows, Thorin awoke to find Gwenyth gone. Panic surged through him as he searched the room, calling her name. He found her on the balcony, perched on the stone railing, gazing out at the snow-covered landscape. She looked back at him, her eyes filled with a wisdom that belied her avian nature.

"Thinking of leaving us, are you?" he asked softly, joining her on the balcony.

Gwenyth cawed, a sound that was both mournful and reassuring. She spread her wings, as if to remind him of her freedom, but she made no move to fly away.

"I understand," Thorin said, his voice choked with emotion. "You are free to go, but know that you always have a home here."

Gwenyth hopped onto his shoulder, nuzzling against his neck. Thorin closed his eyes, savoring the moment. It was then that he realized the depth of his bond with her. She was not just a bird, not just a pet, but a part of his family—a symbol of hope and acceptance.

As the months passed, Gwenyth's presence became a natural part of life in Erebor. The court, once skeptical and disapproving, now embraced her as one of their own. She was a creature of grace and mischief, a source of laughter and comfort. And Thorin, who had faced so much loss and hardship, found a sense of peace in her companionship.

One afternoon, as Thorin and his closest friends gathered in the great hall, Gwenyth swooped down from the rafters, landing on the table with a triumphant caw. In her beak, she held a small, intricately carved ring. Balin leaned forward, his eyes widening in recognition.

"Is that...?" he began, but Thorin interrupted him with a laugh.

"Yes, it is. My grandfather's ring. Lost for decades, and now found by our clever Gwenyth."

The room filled with laughter and applause as Gwenyth strutted around the table, basking in the attention. Thorin reached out to take the ring, his heart swelling with pride and affection.

"You never cease to amaze me," he said, his voice filled with warmth.

Gwenyth hopped onto his arm, her eyes shining with a playful glint. She had brought them more than just a ring; she had brought them together, reminding them of the strength of family and the joy of unexpected bonds.

As the evening wore on and the celebrations continued, Thorin found himself reflecting on the journey that had brought Gwenyth into his life. She had been an outcast, a scruffy young raven with nowhere to go, and yet she had found a place in his heart and home. In her, he saw a reflection of his own struggles and triumphs, a reminder that family was not just about blood, but about the connections we forge and the love we share.

Thorin stood by the fire, Gwenyth perched on his shoulder, and watched as his friends and kin laughed and talked, their faces lit with joy. He felt a deep sense of contentment, knowing that they had all come together, not just as a court, but as a family.

"To family," he whispered, lifting his glass in a silent toast. Gwenyth cawed softly, as if echoing his sentiment.

In that moment, Thorin knew that they were all bound by something greater than duty or obligation. They were bound by love, acceptance, and the unbreakable bonds of family. And as long as they had each other, they would face whatever challenges lay ahead with courage and hope.

Gwenyth, the once scruffy raven, had found her place in their hearts, and in doing so, had reminded them all of the true meaning of family.

writing_prompt: On the coldest night of the year, Merlin braves the frost to gather a rare herb, only to find himself summoned to Arthur's chambers. What begins as a simple scolding over his lack of winter gear turns into an unexpectedly tender moment by the fire.
story:
The cold bit at Merlin's cheeks as he trudged through the dense forest, his breath forming clouds that hung in the frigid air. The moonlight cast an eerie glow on the snow-covered ground, creating long shadows that danced as he moved. He pulled his threadbare cloak tighter around his body, but it did little to ward off the chill. He had been out here for hours, searching for the elusive frostblossom, a rare herb that only bloomed on the coldest nights of the year. Gaius had insisted it was crucial for a remedy he was preparing, and Merlin had volunteered without hesitation. 

His fingers were numb inside his thin gloves, and he could barely feel his toes through his worn boots. The forest was silent, save for the occasional rustle of leaves as a gust of wind swept through the trees. Merlin's eyes scanned the ground, hoping to catch a glimpse of the delicate white petals of the frostblossom. He could feel the weight of exhaustion pressing down on him, but he pushed forward, determined to find the herb.

After what felt like an eternity, Merlin finally spotted a cluster of frostblossoms nestled at the base of a tree. He knelt down, the snow crunching beneath his knees, and carefully picked the flowers, placing them gently in the pouch at his side. A sense of relief washed over him as he stood up, clutching the precious herbs. He turned and began the long trek back to Camelot, the cold seeping deeper into his bones with each step.

By the time he reached the castle gates, the first light of dawn was beginning to creep over the horizon. Merlin's limbs felt like lead, and his vision blurred with fatigue. He stumbled through the courtyard, barely aware of his surroundings. The warmth of the castle walls was a welcome change from the biting cold outside, but it did little to alleviate the exhaustion that weighed him down.

"Merlin!" a voice called out, startling him from his daze. He turned to see one of Arthur's knights striding toward him, a stern expression on his face. "The prince has been looking for you. He wants you in his chambers immediately."

Merlin groaned inwardly. The last thing he needed right now was a scolding from Arthur. But he nodded and followed the knight, his feet dragging as he made his way through the castle corridors. When he reached Arthur's chambers, he took a deep breath and knocked on the door.

"Enter," Arthur's voice called from within.

Merlin pushed the door open and stepped inside. The warmth of the room enveloped him, a stark contrast to the icy cold of the night outside. Arthur was standing by the fire, his arms crossed over his chest, and he fixed Merlin with a disapproving glare.

"Where have you been?" Arthur demanded, his voice tinged with frustration. "Do you have any idea what time it is?"

"I was gathering herbs for Gaius," Merlin replied, his voice hoarse from the cold. "He needed frostblossom for a remedy."

Arthur's eyes narrowed as he took in Merlin's appearance. "And you went out in this weather without proper winter gear? Are you completely mad?"

Merlin opened his mouth to retort, but the words caught in his throat as a violent shiver wracked his body. He swayed on his feet, and Arthur's expression softened slightly.

"Sit down before you fall down," Arthur ordered, gesturing to a chair by the fire.

Merlin didn't argue. He sank into the chair, grateful for the warmth of the flames. Arthur moved to a cabinet and retrieved a thick blanket, draping it over Merlin's shoulders. The prince's hands were surprisingly gentle as he tucked the edges around Merlin's shivering form.

"You really are an idiot sometimes," Arthur muttered, though there was no malice in his tone. "You could have frozen to death out there."

Merlin managed a weak smile. "It was worth it. Gaius needs the herbs."

Arthur shook his head, a small smile playing at the corners of his mouth. "Always thinking of others, even at your own expense."

For a moment, they sat in silence, the crackling of the fire the only sound in the room. Merlin felt the warmth slowly seeping back into his limbs, chasing away the chill. He glanced up at Arthur, who was staring into the flames, a thoughtful expression on his face.

"Why do you do it, Merlin?" Arthur asked quietly. "Why do you always put yourself in harm's way for others?"

Merlin hesitated, unsure how to answer. How could he explain that it was his destiny to protect Arthur, that he was bound by magic and fate to serve the prince? Instead, he settled for a simpler truth.

"Because I care," he said softly. "Because I care about you, about Camelot. It's my home."

Arthur turned to look at him, his blue eyes piercing. "You're a good friend, Merlin. Even if you are a reckless fool."

Merlin chuckled weakly. "I'll take that as a compliment."

Arthur's expression softened further, and he reached out to place a hand on Merlin's shoulder. "Get some rest. You look like you haven't slept in days."

Merlin nodded, feeling the weight of exhaustion pulling him down. He closed his eyes, the warmth of the fire and the comfort of Arthur's presence lulling him into a deep sleep.

When he woke, the room was bathed in the soft light of morning. The fire had burned down to embers, and Arthur was no longer in the room. Merlin stretched, feeling the stiffness in his muscles, but the warmth of the blanket still wrapped around him provided some comfort. He glanced around, noticing a tray of food placed on the table beside him. Arthur must have had it brought in while he slept.

Merlin reached for a piece of bread, his stomach growling in response. As he ate, he couldn't help but reflect on the events of the night before. Arthur's concern for him, the unexpected tenderness in his touch—it was a side of the prince that Merlin rarely saw. Despite the scolding, there was a deep bond between them, one forged through countless trials and shared moments of vulnerability.

As he finished his meal, the door to the chambers opened, and Arthur walked in, looking slightly disheveled but alert. He raised an eyebrow at Merlin, who was still wrapped in the blanket.

"Feeling better?" Arthur asked, his tone casual but his eyes betraying a hint of concern.

"Much," Merlin replied with a smile. "Thanks for letting me rest."

Arthur shrugged, trying to appear nonchalant. "Can't have my servant collapsing from exhaustion, can I? Who else would polish my armor and clean my boots?"

Merlin rolled his eyes, but there was a warmth in his chest that hadn't been there before. "Of course, Your Highness. How could I forget my most important duties?"

Arthur chuckled, the sound genuine and light. "Come on, Merlin. We've got a busy day ahead. And next time you decide to go on one of your late-night herb-gathering expeditions, at least take a proper cloak."

"I'll remember that," Merlin said, standing up and stretching. "And maybe some gloves that actually keep my fingers warm."

Arthur smirked. "I'll see what I can do. Now, hurry up. We've got training to oversee, and I don't want to hear any excuses about being too tired."

Merlin nodded, feeling a renewed sense of purpose. As he followed Arthur out of the chambers, he couldn't help but feel grateful for the unexpected moment of connection they had shared. The cold of the night had been harsh and unforgiving, but the warmth of Arthur's friendship had made it all worthwhile.

The day passed in a blur of activity. Training sessions, errands, and the usual chaos of life in Camelot kept Merlin on his toes. But despite the exhaustion that still lingered at the edges of his mind, he found himself smiling more often than not. Arthur's words and actions from the night before had left a lasting impression, a reminder of the bond that tied them together.

As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the castle, Merlin found himself once again in Arthur's chambers. This time, the atmosphere was relaxed, the fire crackling softly in the hearth. Arthur was seated at his desk, poring over a map, while Merlin busied himself with tidying up.

"You know," Arthur said suddenly, not looking up from his work, "I've been thinking."

"That's dangerous," Merlin quipped, earning a chuckle from Arthur.

"Very funny," Arthur replied dryly. "But seriously, I've been thinking about what you said last night. About caring for Camelot."

Merlin paused in his task, turning to face Arthur. "What about it?"

Arthur leaned back in his chair, his expression contemplative. "It's just... I don't think I ever truly understood how much you do for this kingdom. How much you sacrifice."

Merlin felt a lump form in his throat. "It's my duty," he said simply. "And my choice."

Arthur nodded slowly. "I know. But that doesn't make it any less remarkable."

For a moment, the room was silent, the weight of Arthur's words hanging in the air. Merlin felt a warmth spread through him, a sense of validation and appreciation that he rarely experienced.

"Thank you," Arthur said quietly, his eyes meeting Merlin's. "For everything."

Merlin swallowed hard, a smile tugging at his lips. "You're welcome, Arthur."

The moment stretched between them, filled with unspoken understanding and mutual respect. It was a rare thing, this connection they shared, forged through trials and hardships, but also through small acts of kindness and moments of vulnerability.

As the fire crackled and the shadows lengthened, Merlin felt a sense of peace settle over him. The cold of the night, the exhaustion and the hardships—all of it was worth it for these moments of connection and friendship. In the end, it was not just destiny that bound them together, but a deep and abiding care for one another.

And as long as they had that, Merlin knew they could face whatever challenges lay ahead.

writing_prompt: When Bilbo Baggins left the Shire for his grand adventure, Lobelia Sackville-Baggins saw an opportunity to claim Bag End for herself. But when news of Bilbo's unexpected fate reaches Hobbiton, her plans—and her pride—are thrown into chaos.
story:
Lobelia Sackville-Baggins stood at the edge of the garden of Bag End, her eyes narrowing as she surveyed the lush, well-tended landscape. The garden was teeming with vibrant flowers, their colors a riotous display that seemed to mock her every time she glanced their way. Bag End, with its round door and cozy charm, was everything she had ever wanted. It was a symbol of status, of comfort, of everything that was rightfully hers—or so she believed.

She had heard the whispers, the rumors of Bilbo Baggins' departure on some foolhardy adventure. The old hobbit had always been a bit odd, but this—this was beyond the pale. Who in their right mind would leave the Shire, leave the comfort and safety of Hobbiton, for the unknown dangers of the world beyond?

Lobelia saw opportunity in his madness. With Bilbo gone, Bag End would be hers for the taking. She had already started making plans, discreet inquiries about the legalities of acquiring the property. She could almost feel the cool brass of the door handle under her palm, could almost see herself standing on the threshold, the new mistress of Bag End.

But the news that reached Hobbiton one crisp autumn morning shattered her carefully laid plans. Bilbo Baggins was dead. Or at least, that was what the letter from Gandalf the Grey had implied. The wizard's scrawl was cryptic, but there was no mistaking the somber tone. The dwarves had returned, but Bilbo had not. 

The shock rippled through the community. Bilbo Baggins, the eccentric bachelor who had left the Shire on a whim, was gone for good. The hobbits of Hobbiton mourned in their own way, with solemn nods and whispered condolences. But for Lobelia, the news hit like a physical blow.

She could feel the eyes of the other hobbits on her, their knowing glances and barely concealed smirks. They knew of her ambitions, her relentless pursuit of Bag End. They knew, and they judged. But Lobelia was not one to be easily deterred. She would claim what was rightfully hers, no matter the cost.

Days turned into weeks, and the whispers grew louder. The Sackville-Bagginses were seen more frequently around Bag End, Lobelia making a show of her concern for the property, for dear departed Bilbo. She spoke of the need to maintain the garden, to keep the house in order. She made herself a fixture, an almost spectral presence haunting the periphery of the estate.

It was during one of these visits that she encountered Frodo Baggins, Bilbo's young cousin. He had returned to the Shire, his face pale and drawn, shadows in his eyes that spoke of a burden too heavy for one so young. Frodo had inherited Bag End, as per Bilbo's will, and he had come to claim his inheritance.

"Lobelia," he greeted her with a nod, his voice polite but distant. "I see you've been keeping an eye on the place."

"Someone has to," Lobelia replied, her tone sharp. "With Bilbo gone, it falls to us to ensure his home is cared for."

Frodo's lips twitched in a semblance of a smile. "I appreciate your concern, but Bag End is my responsibility now."

Lobelia bristled. She had expected resistance, but not from Frodo. He was a mere boy, barely out of his tweens, and yet he spoke with an authority that rankled her. "Of course, Frodo," she said, forcing a smile. "But you must understand, Bag End is a significant property. It requires more than just a boy's attention."

Frodo's eyes hardened, and for a moment, Lobelia saw a flicker of something in them that gave her pause. "I assure you, I am more than capable of handling it. Bilbo entrusted it to me, and I will honor his wishes."

The confrontation left Lobelia seething. How dare Frodo, a mere child, stand in the way of her rightful claim? She would not be thwarted by a boy barely out of his childhood. She redoubled her efforts, her schemes growing more elaborate, more desperate.

She sought out allies, other hobbits who might see the sense in her cause. She whispered in ears, sowed seeds of doubt about Frodo's ability to manage such a grand estate. She even went so far as to insinuate that Bilbo's will might be contested, that there might be grounds for a legal challenge.

But Frodo was steadfast. He did not waver, did not falter. He stood his ground, and in doing so, he won the respect of the community. The other hobbits rallied around him, their support bolstering his resolve. Lobelia found herself increasingly isolated, her schemes unraveling before her eyes.

In a final, desperate bid, she confronted Frodo again, this time in the heart of Bag End. She stood in the parlor, surrounded by the trappings of Bilbo's life, the books and trinkets that spoke of a world beyond the Shire. She could feel the weight of history pressing down on her, the judgment of generations of Bagginses who had called this place home.

"Frodo," she began, her voice trembling with barely suppressed rage. "You must see reason. Bag End is too much for you. It should be in the hands of someone who can truly appreciate its worth."

Frodo looked at her, his gaze steady and unyielding. "And you think that someone is you?"

"Yes," she said, her voice rising. "Yes, I do. I have worked my whole life for this. I have sacrificed, I have endured. I deserve this."

Frodo shook his head, his expression one of pity. "Bag End is not a prize to be won, Lobelia. It is a home. It was Bilbo's home, and now it is mine. I will honor his memory, and I will not let you take that from me."

Lobelia felt the ground shift beneath her feet, her dreams crumbling into dust. She had lost. She had gambled everything, and she had lost. The realization was a bitter pill to swallow, her pride stinging like a fresh wound.

In the days that followed, she withdrew from the public eye, her once fierce determination giving way to a weary resignation. She no longer haunted the gardens of Bag End, no longer whispered her schemes in dark corners. She retreated to her own home, her ambitions now nothing more than a distant memory.

And so, Bag End remained in the hands of Frodo Baggins, a symbol of the enduring legacy of Bilbo's adventure. The house stood as a testament to the resilience of the Baggins family, a beacon of hope and stability in a world that had seen its fair share of upheaval.

Lobelia Sackville-Baggins, for all her pride and ambition, had learned a harsh lesson. Bag End was more than just a house. It was a home, a sanctuary, and it belonged to those who understood its true worth. In the end, she had been defeated not by a boy, but by the very essence of the place she had coveted so dearly.

As she sat in her own parlor, staring out at the rolling hills of Hobbiton, Lobelia felt a pang of regret. She had spent so much of her life chasing after something that was never truly hers. And now, in the quiet solitude of her old age, she wondered if perhaps she had missed out on the true treasures of life: family, friendship, and the simple joys of a hobbit's existence.

Bag End remained a distant dream, a symbol of all she had lost. But in its loss, she had gained something far more valuable: a deeper understanding of herself, and a renewed appreciation for the life she had built. It was a humbling lesson, but one that she would carry with her until the end of her days.
